title: Focused Hearing Drives Out All Thought-Processing | Sri Madhu Pandit Dasa | Soulful Japa Training
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: Japa means chanting the holy name, hearing that very name that you chant and tasking to repeat and increase the number of chantings and hearings without any break in attention on the sound.
segments.summary: The speaker defines japa as chanting, hearing, and repeating the holy name with unbroken attention.
segments.transcript: As we have discussed many times, japa means chanting the holy name, hearing that very name that you chant, and tasking to repeat and increase the number of chantings and hearings without any break in attention on the sound. So, mind is always tasking something, either tasking or doing. Suppose I tell you, get me a glass of water. It's a task that your mind will guide your senses. You'll go where the water is and bring the water to me.

segments.key_quote: The mind involves in tasking either a doing or a thinking.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the mind is always engaged in tasking, either in the form of thinking or doing.
segments.transcript: Till then, the mind is engaged in tasking. Do it. Tasking can be done. A tasking can be a doing. A tasking can be a problem solving. Tasking can be a thinking. The mind involves in tasking either a doing or a thinking. For instance, you have a problem. You encounter a problem. Then your mind engages in tasking to find a solution for that. So, the mind is either always tasking. Mind is always tasking, either thinking tasking or doing tasking. Mind is never quiet.

segments.key_quote: The name of the absolute lord, therefore, the name is lord, himself.
segments.summary: The speaker describes japa as meditation on the sound of the Lord's name, which is non-different from the Lord himself, a sound incarnation (Shabda Avatara).
segments.transcript: It is always tasking something. So, in japa, in nama japa, chanting, chanting the holy names of the Lord, it's japa meditation. Meditation on the sound. Because it is not ordinary song. The name of the absolute Lord, therefore, the name is Lord himself. Lord is before you as a sound incarnation, is before you as a Shabda Avatara. As a Shabda Avatara, Avatara means the Lord comes in a very accessible way to our senses. So, Shabda Avatara means the Lord comes, enters a sound in order to give us association. This is called incarnation. So, this sound, Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna, Krishna Krishna, Hare Hare, Hare Ram, Hare Ram, Hare Hare, is not an ordinary sound. It is a sound in which the Lord has entered. It becomes a Lord's sound body. Touching this sound is equal to touching the Lord. The Lord is all pure, all knowledge, all bliss, all love.

segments.key_quote: By hearing, you touch this Lord. When you touch the Lord, then just like a iron put in a fire becomes red hot, transforafiq.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that by chanting and hearing the Hare Krishna mantra, one touches the Lord, leading to purification, enlightenment, and spiritual strength.
segments.transcript: So, by touching the sound, how do you touch the sound? By hearing. By chanting and hearing. By chanting, you invoke the sound. By hearing, you touch this Lord. When you touch the Lord, then just like iron put in a fire becomes red hot, transformed. The same way, by association with the sound through hearing, our consciousness becomes blissful, becomes enlightened as to who we are, that we are eternal beings within this temporary body. We are eternal servants of Krishna. This enlightenment comes in the heart of a person who continuously touches the Hare Krishna Maha Mantra through hearing. segments.key_quote: Hearing means fire is going into your heart. The fire of Satya, Chitta and Ananda.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that concentration in japa means doing only one thing - hearing - and that attention is a tool that can be controlled to invite the Lord into the heart, bringing the fire of eternity, knowledge, and bliss.
